00013 /*  How many contemporary connection should we have. More than one would require
00014  *  mutexe and some modifications to the code, obviously.
00015  *  The real problem here is that the communication with the NXT is slow, so
00016  *  having more than one client that requires data might slow down things more
00017  *  than "a bit".
00018  */
00019 #define BRO_MAX_CONNECTIONS     1

00025     unlink(SERVER_PATH);
00026     exit(EXIT_FAILURE);

00035 int bro_start_server (int * server_sock, int * client_sock)
00036 {
00037     // Variable definitions
00038     int    rc, length;
00039     struct sockaddr_un bro_server;
00040 
00041     // Initializing socket for server
00042     *server_sock = socket(AF_UNIX, SOCK_STREAM, 0);
00043     if (*server_sock < 0) {
00044         perror("socket() failed");
00045         return -1;
00046     }
00047 
00048     // Now we'll get a unique name for our server binding the socket
00049     memset(&bro_server, 0, sizeof(bro_server));
00050     bro_server.sun_family = AF_UNIX;
00051     strcpy(bro_server.sun_path, SERVER_PATH);
00052 
00053     rc = bind(*server_sock, (struct sockaddr *)&bro_server, SUN_LEN(&bro_server));
00054     if (rc < 0) {
00055         perror("bind() failed");
00056         return -1;
00057     }
00058 
00059     enable_cleanup();
00060 
00061     // We'll listen to connections up to a max of BRO_MAX_CONNECTIONS
00062     rc = listen(*server_sock, BRO_MAX_CONNECTIONS);
00063     if (rc< 0) {
00064         perror("listen() failed");
00065         return -1;
00066     }
00067 
00068     printf("Ready for client connect().\n");
00069 
00070     /*
00071      * The server uses the accept() function to accept an incoming
00072      * connection request.  The accept() call will block indefinitely
00073      * waiting for the incoming connection to arrive.
00074      */
00075     *client_sock = accept(*server_sock, NULL, NULL);
00076     if (*client_sock < 0) {
00077         perror("accept() failed");
00078         return -1;
00079     }
00080 
00081     /*  We will use the SO_RCVLOWAT socket option to specify that we don't want
00082      *  recv() to wake up until all sizeof(bro_fist_t) * BUFFER_SIZE of data
00083      *  have arrived.
00084      */
00085     length = sizeof(bro_fist_t) * BUFFER_SIZE;
00086     rc = setsockopt(*client_sock, SOL_SOCKET, SO_RCVLOWAT,
00087                     (char *)&length, sizeof(length));
00088     if (rc < 0) {
00089         perror("setsockopt(SO_RCVLOWAT) failed");
00090         return -1;
00091     }
00092 
00093     return 0;
00094 }

00096 int bro_server_fist (const bro_fist_t * input_fist, bro_fist_t * out_fist,
00097                      int scicos_sock, int spam_sock)
00098 {
00099 
00100     // Variable used to store the communications results.
00101     int rc;
00102 
00103     /*  Check that the sockets are initialized correctly. It's a double check,
00104      *  really, because every connection initialization function has its own
00105      *  way to check if there were some problems. But in these cases it's a good
00106      *  idea to be sure that everything is ok.
00107      */
00108      
00109     assert(scicos_sock >= 0 && spam_sock >= 0);
00110 
00111     //  Let's receive the Fists from the client (Scicos or whatever)
00112     rc = recv(scicos_sock, input_fist, sizeof(bro_fist_t) * BUFFER_SIZE, 0);
00113     if (rc < 0) {
00114         perror("recv() failed");
00115         return -1;
00116     }
00117     
00118     if (rc == 0 || rc < sizeof(bro_fist_t)) {
00119         printf("The client closed the connection before all of the\n");
00120         printf("data was sent\n");
00121         return -1;
00122     }
00123     
00124     //  We are now sending the data to the SPAM and then receive the results...
00125     bro_bt_client_fist (input_fist, out_fist, spam_sock);
00126 
00127     //  Send the data back to the client with the results
00128     rc = send(scicos_sock, out_fist, sizeof(bro_fist_t) * BUFFER_SIZE, 0);
00129     if (rc < 0) {
00130         perror("send() failed");
00131         return -1;
00132     }
00133 
00134     return 0;
00135 
00136 }

00143
